Now that the House has voted to impeach President Trump, I hope each Senator considers their responsibility to our democracy, remembers the oath they took when they first came to the Capitol, and does their part to ensure the fair and honest trial our country needs.

For months, Democrats have urged President Trump and Republicans to listen to patients and drop this partisan and deeply harmful attack on families’ health care—and we’re not going to let up until they do.

Republicans have made their health care vision clear: health care stripped away from people covered by the exchanges or Medicaid expansion; young adults kicked off their parents’ plans; protections for people with pre-existing conditions scrapped; and so much more.

While families still have their coverage and should still seek the care they need, this lawsuit puts health care in our country on a completely avoidable, catastrophic crash course—and unfortunately, that is exactly the outcome President Trump & the GOP have been fighting for.

Today Republicans are closer to getting the health care plan they wanted, in the form of a court ruling on their partisan health care lawsuit that could leave hundreds of millions of people without the coverage and protections they rely on. https://www.help.senate.gov/ranking/newsroom/press/murray-ruling-in-republicans-partisan-lawsuit-puts-health-care-and-protections-for-millions-on-completely-avoidable-catastrophic-crash-course …

We have a responsibility to give students a chance to thrive and be successful. The AHEAD Act would help prevent our most vulnerable youth from falling through the cracks by helping ensure they have the support necessary to complete their education.

Nearly 60% of students experiencing homelessness in WA live outside of city limits. The AHEAD Act would provide vital federal support to help communities across the nation tackle child & family homelessness and improve educational outcomes for students from low-income families.

The AHEAD Act is inspired by partnerships in Seattle & across WA that have brought together housing authorities, school districts, & community partners to provide coordinated support for youth in need—innovative collaborations that have already made a difference.

When children are hungry, sick, or don’t have a place to sleep, it’s harder for them to learn.
 
That’s why I introduced the AHEAD Act—legislation to address the unique challenges faced by youth experiencing homelessness as they pursue an education. https://www.murray.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/newsroom?ID=3948C00C-9DB6-4FAE-9B3D-FE89BD08A591 …

To better support military spouse employment, I’ve been pushing for legislation to expand hiring & career opportunities, improve access to continuing education programs, help ensure access to affordable child care, & provide better transition & employment resources.

I fought for and won an expansion of the crucial VA Caregiver Support Program to veterans of all eras, which provides resources and support for those who put their own lives on hold to care for a veteran with service-connected injuries. #MilitaryFamilyMonth

In order to fulfill our promise to support and care for those who serve our country, we must help and support their families too. That’s why, on the federal level, I’ve worked to strengthen support not just for our servicemembers, but also their families. #MilitaryFamilyMonth

President Trump is the President of the United States, not the president of his extreme right wing base. People want him to:
- stop holding our gov't hostage 
- work w/ Democrats on policies that would actually help workers, women, families, seniors, veterans, & the middle class

But if the Texas lawsuit his administration stands behind goes into effect, children w/ cancer would lose protection for their pre-existing conditions. People who've gained coverage under Medicaid—which is a critical source of coverage for those w/ HIV—would lose their insurance.
The most urgent step we can take right now to help children battling cancer, and help those struggling with HIV, is to make absolutely sure their health care coverage isn’t taken away.

Patients should be able to expect that medical providers and health IT systems vendors will be good stewards of their health data. That means using sensitive information responsibly and empowering patients to control how and when their information is disclosed.
When we talk about making sure we have a strong health IT system, we aren’t just talking about technology and innovation—families’ lives depend on making sure we get this right.

Today electronic health records help doctors across the country identify health problems sooner, avoid medication errors, and make decisions with more knowledge of a patient's medical history. We must continue working to make sure providers and patients can access helpful data.

The Vaccines for Children Program is a great example of investing in prevention. For 25 years now it has helped kids in low income families get shots at no cost. It has saved $1.6T, prevented 380M illnesses, & saved 860,000 lives—that’s more people than the population of Seattle.

Declining vaccination coverage rates are leading to preventable outbreaks. In Clark Co., WA, public health officials continue to respond to a measles outbreak. The immunization rate among children in that community is less than 70%—far below what is needed to keep families safe.

Each case of measles isn’t just a concern for family members worried about loved ones—it’s a threat to neighbors and communities left to contain a contagious disease, a terror for parents with newborns who can’t get vaccinated, and a strain on our public health system.

The measles outbreaks in Washington state and across the country are a clear sign we have to do more to address vaccine hesitancy and make sure parents have the facts they need to understand the science: vaccines are safe, effective, and life-saving.
Vaccines that protect against measles have been in use for over 50 years. We know they are safe, effective, and lifesaving.

I’m going to keep fighting to ensure the @NLRB and the @USEEOC represent all voices—not just those of corporations. I urge every man, woman, and worker who believes that workers should have a voice to join me.

As our nation is grappling with how to address the epidemic of sexual assault & harassment in the workplace, hamstringing the @USEEOC—the agency responsible for protecting workers’ rights & safety—is absolutely the wrong message to send to women, to workers, and to businesses.

The @SenateGOP jammed through Republican nominees to the @NLRB without Mr. Pearce, the Democratic minority nominee—and they allowed one Senator to block Ms. Feldblum's nomination to the @USEEOC, meaning this critical civil rights agency was unable to do its most impactful work.

The @USEEOC and @NLRB are critical agencies responsible for helping protecting workers’ rights, and yet @SenateGOP were more interested in tilting the playing field even more in favor of corporations than providing the EEOC and the NLRB with balanced voices.

I also object to the Senate moving on Republican labor nominees without approving nominations for the @USEEOC and the @NLRB. Even though Chai Feldblum and Mark Pearce were highly qualified nominees and respected by their peers, @SenateGOP refused to give them a vote.

Cheryl Stanton has a long history of siding with employers when they’ve violated workers’ rights, & she should not lead the division that enforces some of our nation's most important workplace laws, including the federal minimum wage, child labor laws, & family & medical leave.

Heading to the Senate floor to speak about my opposition to the nomination of Cheryl Stanton to serve as Administrator for the @USDOL's Wage and Hour Division. I'm voting NO on her nomination and I urge my colleagues to do the same.

Each of us will have to put aside every other consideration beyond the facts, & focus solely on preserving the integrity of our democracy and upholding our solemn obligation to defend the Constitution. 

And history will record where we all stand.

If & when the House elects to accuse the president of an impeachable offense or offenses, the Senate will host the trial, and Senators will serve as jurors.

If and when that time comes, I know I will approach the matter seriously—& I deeply hope each of my colleagues will, too.

I’ve sat as a juror in an impeachment trial before. 

It was a deeply serious undertaking—and one each Member took seriously before rendering a decision. 

That is the same seriousness required in this moment.

I believe that this country is a country of laws. 

I believe our elections must be completely free from foreign interference. 

And I believe that every elected official should ensure these fundamental principles come before party or partisanship as this process moves forward.

It would be a dereliction of duty for Congress not to investigate the grave threats to our country’s safety & our democratic institutions. 

If President Trump & his administration have nothing to hide they should stop obstructing & let Congress do its job to find all the facts.

For me and for so many other people across the country, this isn’t about partisan politics—or any politics. 

This is about maintaining our nation’s security and defending the rule of law. 

This is about nothing less than the future of our democracy.

There are still many questions about the President & his associates’ actions—and the American people deserve answers. 

That’s why the House was right to begin impeachment proceedings.

The President has repeatedly sought foreign interference in our elections, which we should all find appalling. 

These facts are indisputable and can’t be spun. President Trump & his sidekicks have been clear about their actions & intentions—and it is clear they are unacceptable.

Let’s start with what we know for sure: President Trump & his associates pushed the Ukrainian gov’t to launch an investigation, without basis, into the President’s political opponents to help his election. 

Then, he made overtures to China—out in the open—to do the same.

Our nation is at a crossroads that strikes at the heart of our democracy.

The outrageous actions of President Trump & his administration have brought us to this moment, & we should step back to discuss how much is truly at stake for our country if we don’t get this right.
HAPPENING NOW: I’m on my way to the Senate floor to speak on the House’s impeachment inquiry and the grave threat President Trump’s actions pose to our safety and democracy.
